contentrichtext.text: The '''Grand National Alliance''' (''Gran Alianza Nacional'', GANA) is a [[right-wing]] [[political party]] in [[Guatemala]]. The acronym "GANA" also spells out the word ''gana'', from the verb ''ganar'', "to win". [[File:GANA Logo.svg|thumb|right|200px|Logo]] ==Formation and 2003 election== GANA was created as an electoral alliance to fight the [[Guatemalan general election, 2003|2003 general election]]. In that election, held on 9 November 2003, the Grand National Alliance, won 24.3% of the vote, and 47 out of 158 seats in [[Congress of Guatemala|Congress]]. The [[President of Guatemala|presidential]] candidate of the alliance, [[Óscar Berger Perdomo]], won 34.3% at the presidential elections of the same day. He won 54.1% at the second round and was elected president. The alliance was made up of the following parties: *[[Patriotic Party (Guatemala)|Patriotic Party]] (Partido Patriota) (PP) *[[Reform Movement (Guatemala)|Reform Movement]] (Movimiento Reformador) (MR) *[[National Solidarity Party (Guatemala)|National Solidarity Party]] (Partido Solidaridad Nacional) (PSN) ==Evolution and 2007 election== The Patriotic Party broke with the alliance in the early months of Óscar Berger's administration. [http://www.lahora.com.gt/04/05/20/paginas/opinion.htm#n8] In November 2005, the National Solidarity Party ceded its electoral registration to GANA, with which the Grand National Alliance ceased to be an alliance and became a party. In August 2006, the Reform Movement withdrew its support from GANA. [http://www.fundadesc.org/archivo/sesentaycuatro/analisis.htm] GANA's candidate in the [[Guatemalan general election, 2007|2007 presidential election]] was former director of the national prison service [[Alejandro Giammattei]]. He came in third place in the election, with 17% of the vote. Despite the splits in the party, it did relatively well in the congressional elections, receiving 37 seats and becoming the second largest party in Congress. ==External links== *[http://www.gana.com.gt/nhistoria.htm GANA web site] {{Guatemalan political parties}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2010}} [[Category:Political parties in Guatemala]] {{Guatemala-party-stub}}
